messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Cross-Layer Encrypted Semantic Communication Framework for Panoramic Video Transmission

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper, we propose a cross-layer encrypted semantic communication (CLESC) framework for panoramic video transmission, incorporating feature extraction, encoding, encryption, cyclic redundancy check (CRC), and retransmission processes to achieve compatibility between semantic communication and traditional communication systems. Additionally, we propose an adaptive cross-layer transmission mechanism that dynamically adjusts CRC, channel coding, and retransmission schemes based on the importance of semantic information. This ensures that important information is prioritized under poor transmission conditions. To verify the aforementioned framework, we also design an end-to-end adaptive panoramic video semantic transmission (APVST) network that leverages a deep joint source-channel coding (Deep JSCC) structure and attention mechanism, integrated with a latitude adaptive module that facilitates adaptive semantic feature extraction and variable-length encoding of panoramic videos. The proposed CLESC is also applicable to the transmission of other modal data. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed CLESC effectively achieves compatibility and adaptation between semantic communication and traditional communication systems, improving both transmission efficiency and channel adaptability. Compared to traditional cross-layer transmission schemes, the CLESC framework can reduce bandwidth consumption by 85% while showing significant advantages under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The power of data: how traffic demand and data analytics are driving network evolution toward 6G systems",
        "6G vision: an ultra-flexible perspective",
        "6G wireless communications: from far-field beam steering to near-field beam focusing",
        "Toward immersive communications in 6G",
        "Toward wisdom-evolutionary and primitive-concise 6G: a new paradigm of semantic communication networks",
        "Communication beyond transmitting bits: semantics-guided dource and channel coding",
        "Semantic communications: overview, open issues, and future research directions",
        "TCP/IP tutorial and technical overview",
        "Nonlinear transform source-channel coding for semantic communications",
        "Wireless deep video semantic transmission",
        "Semantic coding for text transmission: an iterative design",
        "Semantic communication systems for speech transmission",
        "Semantic communication-enabled wireless adaptive panoramic video transmission",
        "Rate splitting multiple access-enabled adaptive panoramic video semantic transmission",
        "End-to-end optimized 360° image compression",
        "Deep contextual video compression",
        "Weighted-to-spherically-uniform quality evaluation for omnidirectional video",
        "Weighted-to-spherically-uniform SSIM objective quality evaluation for panoramic video",
        "Semantic communications in networked systems: a data significance perspective",
        "Knowledge-enhanced semantic communication system with OFDM transmissions",
        "Latent semantic diffusion-based channel adaptive de-noising semcom for future 6g systems",
        "SemHARQ: Semantic-Aware HARQ for Multi-task Semantic Communications",
        "Deep source-channel coding for sentence semantic transmission with HARQ",
        "DeepJSCC-Q: Constellation constrained deep joint source-channel coding",
        "Joint coding-modulation for digital semantic communications via variational autoencoder",
        "A survey of cross-layer designs in wireless networks",
        "Cross-layer design proposals for wireless mobile networks: a survey and taxonomy",
        "An adaptive cross-layer design approach for network security management",
        "Improving TCP performance for wireless cellular networks by adaptive FEC combined with explicit loss notification",
        "CDMA/HDR: a bandwidth efficient high speed wireless data service for nomadic users",
        "A transcoding-enabled 360 VR video caching and delivery framework for edge-enhanced next-generation wireless networks",
        "Taming the latency in multi-user VR 360°: A QoE-aware deep learning-aided multicast framework",
        "Reliability enhancement for VR delivery in mobile-edge empowered dual-connectivity sub-6 GHz and mmWave HetNets",
        "Power-efficient wireless streaming of multi-quality tiled 360 VR video in MIMO-OFDMA systems",
        "NOMA assisted two-tier VR content transmission: a tile-based approach for QoE optimization",
        "DeepWiVe: Deep-learning-aided wireless video transmission",
        "Advanced encryption standard (AES) algorithm to encrypt and decrypt data",
        "ChaCha20-Poly1305 authenticated encryption for high-speed embedded IoT applications",
        "Optimization of cyclic redundancy-check codes with 24 and 32 parity bits",
        "A survey on protograph LDPC codes and their applications",
        "NR; Physical layer procedures for data",
        "DeepJSCC-f: deep joint source-channel coding of images with feedback",
        "Wireless multiplayer interactive virtual reality game systems with edge computing: modeling and optimization",
        "Informed dynamic scheduling for belief-propagation decoding of LDPC codes",
        "A majority voting technique for wireless intrusion detection systems",
        "Density modeling of images using a generalized normalization transformation",
        "CBAM: convolutional block attention module",
        "End-to-end optimized image compression",
        "Swin transformer v2: scaling up capacity and resolution",
        "Omnidirectional video super-resolution using deep learning",
        "Gaze prediction in dynamic 360 immersive videos",
        "Overview of the H. 264/AVC video coding standard",
        "Overview of the high efficiency video coding (HEVC) standard"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Cross-Layer Encrypted Semantic Communication Framework for Panoramic Video Transmission, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
